Academics who obviously live a life focused around elite University campuses and go only to parties where everyone is employed as a university academic, or in some New York City cultural circles, write fiction like 'The Netanyahus'. Joshua Cohen's novel is centered around two scholarly Jews and their families, their minutely dissected but competing ideas about history and religion, and the job of being a university academic in a primarily Western Protestant college world. American academics or the academic-minded usually write fiction about university life like this one as a kind of slap(stick) about what, I guess, is how viciously academics really despise each other behind their walled gardens of high-minded intellectualism. I have read some other current literary authors popular with academia and the intelligentsia before, usually people who live around New England and that Motherland of White Tower novels, England. The English novels are more politely obscure in their plots and seemingly try very hard to appear unconscious of their class snobbery or of the fact that their books will be read only by intellectual literary snobs to the last page (or by the curious, or the sometimes self-taught wilders like me). American academic writers are more open about the class snobbery of intellectuals and write plots more aware that their subject matter is esoteric and stiflingly boring to most people. But the authors know they will get high praise in literary circles and maybe awards! What does it matter if the book only sells, perhaps, 30,000 copies, mostly to libraries?Frankly, if intellectual Jews are STILL going on and on (for millennia) with the arguments about what being Jewish is, about the hatreds within and without the world of Judiasm, about whether their sufferings are commanded by God, and about the right of Israel to be a Jewish Homeland, even if it is done by a jaundiced eye by a clever author, I am very disheartened. So. 'The Netanyahus' is boring for TWO reasons then. At least, for the seasoned readers.The true-believer myopia of all arguments and prejudices within religions is disheartening to me, actually, but especially those two-dimensional believers in the Abrahamic religions. The fact that many male demigogues are elected to office (or are given tenure) because they are populist theological demigogues is awful, too. I suppose laughing at everyone's manners and grossly myopic politics is all an author can do. I'm on Cohen's side on this. But why withhold the introduction of the Netanyahus until page 130, almost two-thirds into the novel? Cohen based this novel on a supposedly true anecdote about Ben-Zion Netanyahu, father of the Benjamin Netanyahu who is an infamous Israel politician. Cohen fills out the book with the backstory of Ben-Zion's ideas, why American academics embraced him as a university lecturer, and what Ben and his siblings were like as children. Although the book is an insider one humorously skewering academia and the being a token Jew among Eastern American Protestants, and how a second- and third-generation American Jew meeting an old-school European zionist Jew is shocked, especially by a zionist Jew with a unique acceptance of intolerance and hate because they believe intolerance and hate are a Good to be encouraged (on several levels), I found the book yet another meta-literary conversation of yet another Jewish generation going over the same ground again. On one hand, it's good that conversation is happening, on the other, it's horrible the conversation is happening again. No religion, even one of the oldest Abrahamic ones, can stop disputing viewpoints of what a believer should believe, and political infighting again cycles and recycles generation after generation. Hilariously sad.

When the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction was announced this year, I screwed up my face in a rictus of incredulity: I'd never heard of Joshua Cohen's The Netanyahus. It's an experience I imagine was shared by readers who keep an eye to book prizes. Typically I've heard of the winner before it's announced, but it was a treat to have an introduction through the prize. The style and density of the novel makes it a bit of a Pulitzer anomaly in my mind, but I can also see how the committee would want to highlight such a unique novel.The Netanyahus is a fictionalized version of a second-hand account of a visit from the world's worst house guests. While the eponymous family definitely takes centre stage in the later half of the novel, the main theme asks what it means to be an American Jew. The reader is led through the proceedings by Dr. Blum, a history professor at a mediocre university, who struggles with his family and identity. Now, had the novel been only the riotously funny social encounters I'm sure I would have been entirely enamoured with the whole thing. However, there's patches of oratory, exposition, and history that are bolstered with a thesaurus worth of diction making for some exceedingly dense passages. I struggled through these bits having very little footing in the historical plight of the Jewish people outside of the 20th and 21st centuries. I definitely learned some things, but I think I would have enjoyed it more had I come prepared for hefty passages of, essentially, nonfiction. Having read two Pulitzer Prize winners for fiction in as many months, I much prefer Cohen's quirky and wordy romp to Louise Erdrich's The Night Watchman. There's an undeniable charm to Cohen's thick writing and the ending is a laugh-out-loud affair that had me in stitches. In the end, pretty darned good, but not easy.

Discussions regarding The Netanyahus revolve around two questions: 1) Why did this under-the-radar novel win the Pultizer Prize, and 2) Is it any good. The quality and literary merit of The Netanyahus has garnered both praise and ire. A BookTuber whose channel I've been following for several years recently uploaded an exoricating review of the novel that you can view here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BSS6e.... Challenging as this novel may be for some readers, I found Joshua Cohen's seemless blend of fiction, nonfiction, history, religion, and politics masterfully executed. The result is an enthralling text that links the past to the present in stunning fashion.At its core, The Netanyahus is a campus novel but its forays into dense academic prose will try some readers' patience. I went all in for those sections and unlike other readers I took delight in happening upon those hundred-dollar SAT words Cohen sprinkled throughout the text (more on that later). Ruben Blum, the narrator, is a man perplexed by his private life and his professional circumstances as the only Jewish faulty member at a small liberal arts college in New York state. Practically strongarmed into hosting Ben-Zion Netanyahu, who hopes to land a teaching position at Ruben's college, Ruben is like a spindly tree in a hurricane when Netanyahu and his family arrive at his home, a meeting that forces Ruben to wrestle with Jewish history and solidarity, the purpose of education, anti-Semitism, masculinity, and a whirlwind of other issues. The Netanyahus may be a challenging book, and Cohen, much like Netanyahu, does not apologize for his erudition or endeavor to simplify his text to make it more accessible to readers. I truly admire that. In an era where so many literary fiction offerings have the same MFA workshop burnish to them, it's refreshing to encounter a book that puts demands on readers. This is espeically true in Cohen's diction. Folks, you will absolutely need to keep a dictionary close at hand when you read this book. As wide as my vocabulary is, even I was knocked sideways by the language. But I loved coming across those words; they kept me active in the reading, as if I were hunting for treasure. I'm glad that in this current trend of literary minimalism, Cohen has the guts to force readers to take the job of reading seriously and raise stakes for us. Anyone who thinks Cohen choice of words is pretentious or snobbish should just avoid this book.But it is also important to remember that Cohen is writing out of a long tradition of Jewish literature, encompassing Philip Roth to Saul Bellow to Adam Levin and others. Long, digressive stories are par for the course, and internecine questions regarding Jews' place in society and their commitment to the community expand the corpus of Jewish literature. Did The Netanyahus derseve to win the Pulitzer Prize? I believe so, but that doesn't mean there weren't plenty of other books that could easily have taken the win (personally, I thought it was going to go to Crossroads by Jonathan Franzen, a similar novel released in 2021). Awards are about many things. The timeliness of The Netanyahus' release, just around the time Benjamin Netanyahu had been removed from office only to be reinstated months later, says a great deal. Love it or hate it, this novel captures an important moment in history, and in a strange way it does so twice.

The funniest book I've read since perhaps The Sellout, the language was also superbly crafted from the very first page, and it all very thought provoking as well.The book is a fictionalized account of a real event: Ben-Zion Netanhayu's visit to Cornell for a job talk in the 1960. This was not, however, any job talk as the University found their only Jewish professor and put him on the search committee even though it was outside his area, had him host Netanyahu, who ends up without telling anyone showing up with his wife and three bratty children (one of whom is Bibi Netanyahu). Joshua Cohen uses a fictional stand-in for Cornell and the Cornell professor (although all is eventually revealed), but draws realistically from Ben-Zion Netanyahu's biography and scholarship, and then presumably makes up an awful lot else.The Netanyahus fits into the genre of campus novel with its slightly satirical and amused descriptions of the minutiae and silliness of the practices on campus, who serves on what committee, who teaches what, which department gets the resources, etc. But it does it while also depicting American Jews in the late 1950s, the conflict between religion (on one side of the family) and secularism (on the other), the combination of anti-semitism, tokenism, and just well-meaning people unsure how to behave, and the like.And then into this we hear a little about Netanyahu, then we get a glowing portrait of him from a recommendation letter that is printed in full, and then we get a more candid and negative portrayal, and finally the character himself enters and he is a bully, a brute, and the rest of his family members are even worse, and yet his Jewish host is meek and permissive in the face of them, unable to stand up to any of it until it goes to extreme lengths.As such it also fits into the genre of Jewish comic novels, with Cohen stylizing himself (and referring to) the tradition of Bernard Malamud, Saul Bellow, and Philip Roth with humor that is both a combination of outrageous, things that should not have been said, and also a meek way of deflecting and avoiding confrontation with the problems of the world.Mostly, however, the book is pure fun, funniness, and delightful writing from the first page to the last.

What a ride! This book combines several things very skillfully, managing to be thoughtful and perceptive and also just wildly hilarious in its depiction of the ungovernable Netanyahus as they descend like a whirlwind on a small New York state college. [There‚Äôs added pleasure in learning from the author‚Äôs afterword that this is a thinly veiled, fictionalized account of the real-life 1960 encounter between future academic luminary Harold Bloom and Jewish historian Benzion Netanyahu (father of Benjamin ‚ÄúBibi‚Äù Netanyahu, future Prime Minister of Israel), visiting Bloom‚Äôs college to interview for a teaching post.]Ruben Blum is a young history professor hoping for tenure at a small New York college in a completely white-bread town. He is the only Jewish employee at the college, faculty or staff, and he and his family are the only Jews in town. Ruben is subject to the constant ‚Äúgenteel‚Äù anti-Semitism of colleagues, and the latest example is that he‚Äôs not only been reluctantly co-opted to serve on the hiring committee to assess the candidacy of a Jewish historian (and historian of the Jews in medieval Spain, especially during the Inquisition) but has also been dragooned into hosting him. Benzion shows up unexpectedly accompanied by his bellicose wife and equally aggressive three sons, and they all quickly proceed to trash the Blum‚Äôs home. Netanyahu‚Äôs sample lesson to a Bible-studies class and public lecture (both part of the hiring process) are very interesting and illuminating (to this reader anyway) but jaw-droppingly ill-suited for a hopeful job candidate. (Talk about shooting yourself in the foot.) There‚Äôs a lot to unpack in a shortish serio-comic novel, but Cohen puts it all together masterfully.

Of course my enjoyment of the book was only enhanced by meeting the author and having him sign it for me first, but I still think this was a significant step up from Moving Kings, my only previous encounter with his work. It's a campus novel that is properly funny. Perhaps the funniest since Lucky Jim. It's also very specifically about the nature of Jewishness in America at the start of the 1960s. Perhaps parallels could be drawn with Jewishness in America today and its relation to unapologetic, right-wing Israel. In 1960 a Jew in America is trying to keep his head down and fly under the radar until he is reminded of his otherness and embarrassed by the crassness of an Israeli. I guess that may resonate for some in the here and now.Calling the book "The Netanyahus" is mere sleight of hand. You are looking in one direction while something else entirely is going on. Something richer and more rewarding. Of course there is enough early Zionist history and outright ridiculing of the young Bibi to satisfy people who turned up for the title, but the focus of the novel is the assimilating diaspora Jew, not the Zionist in exile.

"And so my childhood was tugged between conflicting exceptionalisms, between the American condition of being able to choose and the Jewish condition of being chosen."It is 1960 and Ruben Blum is a college professor in upstate New York who is the only Jewish man in town. That is until he is assigned to host Zionist historian Benzion Netanyahu and his rambunctious family in home. What ensues is nothing short of hilarity and an intelligent tale while the push and pull of protagonist Blum and the overly antagonistic Netanyahu explore themes of identity, fairness, history and theology. Part campus novel part political statement, Joshua Cohen has created something special with The Netanyahus."Today in America, I suspect that revisionism means much the same, only within the context of another power structure: the insistence on writing history in such a way that unsettles what's called a ruling-class and interferes with the functioning of government and business. He is a perfect contrast to Blum who tries to see fairness and possibility to not live in history repeating itself when it comes to the Jewish people. We learn about Jewish history and the Zionist movement and the differing sects within it."But the past doesn't have to be the future. That's the point of something you aspire to."The Netanyahus by Joshua Cohen is a humorous and intellectual take on themes post war American life and the Jewish diaspora. Joshua Cohen has a way with words, and the ability to make one think and laugh out loud, sometimes at the same time. Though the story went kind of off the rails near the end, I found myself intellectually stimulated and pleasantly entertained by The Netanyahus. If you're looking for stirring syntax, a good laugh while learning something, you can't go wrong with this Pulitzer Prize winning novel by Joshua Cohen. "What else is salient? I wish I knew. But do we ever know?""I'd like to think my profession has made me more attuned than most to the selective use of facts and the way that each age and ideological movement manages to cobble together its own tailormade chronicles to suit its aims and glatter its self-conceptions.""The past was merely the process by which the present was attained, and the present merely the most current stage of the American superlative, to be overtaken by tomorrow's liberation and capital's spread, until the ultimate transfiguration of world history into world democracy.""The plunger gave gasps like wet flatulence.""She had that smart cruelty of someone who'd gotten what she wanted. And she'd gotten it the fairest way, through suffering.""I asked whether you think it's fair that by making a study of your faith, you lose it?""Perhaps I should just conclude with the antagonism between the belief that history never repeats itself and the belief that it always repeats itself, in the very circular eternity of this table.""History treats time as a chain of happenings that we humans set into motion by our own free will: its first lesson is that a first cause does not exist because, as my teachers put it back in public school, we learn history in order to learn how to change it. I thoroughly enjoyed this even in spite of the author's ostentatious overachieving (see the vocabulary list below). The two most enjoyable scenes involved, first, the protagonist's hilariously judgmental in-laws visiting his house, critiquing every piece of furniture and decor. Second, when the Netanyahu family finally arrives in the novel, on p. 135. Protagonist Ruben Blum teaches history at a middling upstate New York college. Because he's the only Jew on campus, he is assigned to welcome the new Israeli professor Benzion Netanyahu, who arrives with his wife and three young sons. The whole family is horrific. It's snowing outside but they refuse to take off their shoes when asked; they stain the carpet, grab up knick-knacks, bang on the piano, 7-year-old Iddo rubs fireplace ashes on his face, mother Tzila lays him on a tray table to change his diaper as brother Benjamin finger-flicks his penis, then because they have no fresh underwear, Tzila places a square of toilet paper over his boyhood. Benzion has borrowed a local rabbi's car and gotten into an accident that damaged the grille, and now wants Blum to lie and write a letter explaining that there are no mechanics in town available to service the car. "They're so horrible, so pushy," complains Blum's wife Edith to him in the kitchen. The scene goes on for more than twenty pages and it's not the end of the Blums' suffering: later, the Netanyahu children will break the Blums' new color TV and the eldest Netanyahu child Jonathan will seduce Blum daughter Judy while future prime minister Benjamin watches.Cohen explains in an afterword that the inspiration for the novel came from Harold Bloom, a mentor and the book's dedicatee. On one of their last visits Bloom told Cohen about "the time he was asked to coordinate the campus visit of an obscure Israeli historian named Ben-Zion Netanyahu, who showed up for a job interview and lecture with his wife and three children in tow and proceeded to make a mess."The plot and the prose flow along nicely, but it's hard to ignore all the big words Cohen tosses around. Caudillo, glabrous, sudorous, lucubration, frum, yecca, nugatory, midden, meekened, entelechy, ponton, labent, proboscine, pelage, heliumated, sere, mittened, eisegetical, sublunary, hyemal, glorioled, pentimento, recense, capirote, hidalgo, connate, tenebrous, coruscant, carceral, serried, horripilated. Another oddity was the use of "diningroom" rather than dining room. You wouldn't notice this once or twice, but Cohen used it eight times.

Once a book wins a Pulitzer Prize, it gains not only well-deserved attention, but also a type of immortality for having been awarded America‚Äôs most prestigious literary distinction. I‚Äôm a year late opening the 2022 Pulitzer-winner for fiction The Netanyahus: An Account of a Minor and Ultimately Even Negligible Episode in the History of a Very Famous Family, and it‚Äôs not the variety of memorable winner for me that I hoped for.It‚Äôs pedantic and tedious to where it gave me a headache trying to keep up with the cumbersome, lumbering sentences that stacked up like endless lists of obscure, erudite insights and descriptions. With that said, Cohen‚Äôs knowledge and intellect are impressive, and he possesses a skill for cleverness and humor that is easily apparent. The problem is that he buries his cleverness and humor with limitless telling and an accumulation of details before actually giving us the story in between. Then he labors out the story so slowly, again buried with a tonnage of academic and scholarly minutiae.The story, when there is one, deals with Professor Ruben Blum who is chosen to host Israeli scholar Benzion Netanyahu at Corbin College, a fictionalized university in not-quite northern New York. What constitutes the narrative could have worked better as a short story. To the contrary, it‚Äôs incredibly slogged out to the point of yawning and exhaustion. High-level scholarship on Jewry and Jewish history is loaded up throughout, and so too are the obvious laughs intended, but the story lacks.A much more rollicking and brilliantly comedic and satirical campus novel is Richard Russo‚Äôs Straight Man. As for more ingenious dry and dark humor and more piercing drama about the Jewish experience, seek out the incomparable Philip Roth‚Äôs oeuvre. In particular, I‚Äôll suggest the works of his that have made an indelible impact on me: The Ghost Writer, The Counterlife, Operation Shylock, American Pastoral, I Married a Communist, and The Human Stain.

This book flew under my radar until Monday, when it was named as the winner of the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction. I immediately used an Audible credit to purchase it.Over the past few years I have read several novels by Philip Roth, Saul Bellow, and Bernard Malamud. However, as a middle aged woman born in Iowa, and raised in Colorado, I have had very little exposure to Jewish culture, history and thought. My knowledge and understanding is negligible. Going into this one, I wish that I had more background first.The Netanyahus felt completely unique and the writing is brilliant. I laughed aloud several times. I stopped my book and rewound in order to listen to the well-crafted passage a second time. I appreciated the unique storytelling style which combined real people with fictional, actual history moments of imagination, and satire with realism. However, (and this is perhaps due to the missing chunks of my knowledge) I couldn't find a deeply resonant connection with the characters.What did work extremely well for me, was the examination of what it means to be Jewish. I loved the author's deft portrayal of contrast. The fictional narrator's way of living life in midcentury America was to assimilate (to perhaps hide much of his Jewishness) and to be moldable, progressive and pliant. Cohen sets this against the real man, Benzion Netanyahu, who is the opposite, an unbending Zionist who believes that the Jew must not assimilate. He is a harsh, brash, antagonistic man who is seen as a fanatic even by Israel. This is a story that resonates with me, as the opposing views of right and left, black and white, religious and nonreligious, and conservative and liberal, tend to have these kinds of contrast and frustration.I am glad to have read it, but I think perhaps I will need to attack this one again after more exposure to Jewish literature and thought.

The Netanyahus is an ageless masterpiece at multiple levels. The language, to start with, showcases a literary genius at work. The reviewer felt that his vocabulary was shamefully inadequate all through, but frequent runs to the dictionary did not make the prose any less joyful. The descriptions, statement structures, and dialogues will keep any collector of quotable quotes busy with their highlighters and the non-collectors mesmerized.Rivaling the language is the book's wit. Superficially, the jokes are based on time-worn subterfuges involving eccentric personalities, clumsy actions, and embarrassing outcomes. However, the intelligent undercurrents move the story forward in powerful ways and create easy avenues for rather intricate and serious discussions on various political and historical matters.And the book is about the Jews in various communities, including within their own - as individuals carrying interpretations of the collective history. Like in real life, the book's Jews come in all varieties. What binds them is more than just religion (or even "race," as the book expounds on) but the sufferings of their ilk for millennia. The story shows the difference between what the outsiders simply see as one whole is a set of individuals with divisions as pronounced as their common denominators. Above all, it is about the Israeli leader in his formative years and his family in a fictionalized, humourous setting. Through his parents, particularly his father, the author shines the light on the possible genesis of his current orthodox views. Although never overtly, the author finds rather innovative ways to discuss relevant episodes of the near- and far-pasts to build the case.There is a lot to enjoy and learn, even more to ponder on in this intelligent work.

Campy and funny, "The Netanyahus" is a fictional account of Ben-Zion Netanyahu's visit to a university in the US once upon a time, where it turned out the man had brought his family in tow and 'proceeded to make a mess'. As the details of the actual visit remain relatively unknown (the anecdotal story was related to Cohen by Harry Bloom, who had been the one to handle the visit), Cohen took some creative licenses to speculate on what might have happened on that day, so it's best to treat this book as 90% fiction and roll with it.The offbeat humor here lies in Cohen's writing, where the snappy dialogues and the almost slapstick comedy made me feel like I was watching one of those 1940s movies. Blume's inner dialogue tickled me to no end (the Church of Assumption was a nice touch), but there are also heavy discussions of history and theology, and the blurred lines between those two, especially once the titular character made his appearance. The themes of identity and tokenism within academia and/or the corporate world was also discussed within the narrative to great effect, considering this barrier still exists for POCs and women.While I enjoyed this, it's probably not for those who are easily offended by fictional portrayals of real-life people because Cohen's version of Netanyahu leaves readers no doubt as to which side of the fence he stood at.

This book is a nominee for the 2021 National Book Critics Circle Award. While this is not one of the awards that I regularly read the nominees for, when I realized it was the only one on the list I had not read, I decided I needed to be a completist. I enjoyed it as I did most of the books on the list. It is a strange but clever novel that apparently has a true story as its core, one that the author was told by critic Harold Bloom. Ruben Blum is the only Jewish professor (teaching the history of taxation) at a small liberal arts college in upstate New York (upstate NY, like the Pennsylvania T, is right of center country). Blum and his wife are not religious and would just like to blend in. Their daughter Judy is at the top academically in her class and very desirous of getting her nose fixed. The two sets of grandparents are almost complete opposites, with Blum's parents being hard working, lower middle-class, religious Jews and his wife's parents being rich, not-so-religious Jews (think of Mrs. Maisel's parents from the TV comedy Mrs. Maisel). Blum is asked to be part of the history department's hiring committee that has been told it will lose a chunk of its budget if it does not hire a professor to share with the religion department. A candidate has been recommended - Benzion Netanyahu (a real life figure - zionist and father of recent Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu). The Department head asks Blum to check Netanyahu out. Blum figures he was added to the committee only because he is Jewish. Blum is to host Netanyahu when he comes for his campus visit, at which he will not only meet the hiring committee but also give a public lecture and teach a Bible class at the campus chapel. Unexpected by everyone at the college, Netanyahu shows up at Blum's house with his wife and their three children, all of whom behave badly.The author's afterward describes how he got to know Harold Bloom and hear the Netanyahu story.

I loved this book for the way it made me, as a Jew, think deeply on issues of identity. To me, this book was all about what it means to be a American Jew in a post 1948 world. It‚Äôs first half, which details the history of the fictional Blum and his family, seemed to me to encapsulate a lot of aspects of the Jewish American experience: It showed how many communities of diverse experience from around the world bubbled and boiled in the American melting pot to create a somehow ancient somehow brand-new diaspora identity the members of which, while definitely distinct from Christian America, are not fully sure of who they are or to what extent they should assimilate.The book also brilliantly lays out how the Diaspora Jews (though this statement applies to the diaspora at large, I should acknowledge that this book focuses mainly on the US Jewish experience) is in a very complicated relationship with the other half of the Jewish community: the Israeli Jews. Listened to audiobookThis is a difficult book for me to rate. I found some parts funny, others sad, and a good portion of it confusing or just over my head. I think there is something to be said for my gross lack of knowledge or understanding of Jewish culture and history, which definitely left me feeling ill-equipped to fully grasp references or inferences that those more steeped in this tradition would know and appreciate. The most enjoyable chapters were spent with the Blum family. They contain equal parts absurd comedy and relatable family conflict. The lectures and letters and history portions of the book were the most difficult for me, and my brain tended to wander during parts of them. Not because of any disinterest, but rather due to my ignorance in the subject.A question that Cohen seems to be hinting at through the novel is "What does it mean to be Jewish in America?" Or even more broadly it may be "What does it mean to be American?". This contemplation is played out in the Blum's household through the family dynamics, as well as in the scholarly halls of the college campus in which the main character, Ruben Blum, is a professor. Both in his career and in his familial role, Ruben tends to go along to get along. He takes no particular stance on his Jewish heritage, neither culturally nor religiously, and is often being put in the center of conflicts or situations that show the reader his lack of conviction. Despite this, he begins to acknowledge to himself that perhaps his constant placating and lack of established identity is harmful -not only to himself, but to his family. The most powerful example is in the character of his daughter, Judy. She is fully immersed in American culture, and seems to have no consideration for her Jewish heritage. In fact, she is so determined to fit into her American world, that she longs (and goes to great lengths) to completely change a physical characteristic that signifies her lineage. This comes to head in a funny yet heartbreaking scene which prompts more inward contemplation from Ruben to wrestle with the past, present, and future, and what that looks like for a Jew in America.The Netanyahus come barging in late in the book, and they certainly make an impression. Honestly, I am a little confused by what exactly they represent, since I know little of Jewish politics and not much about Netanyahu himself. Read for the 2022 PopSugar reading challenge. I'm calling this "A book that features two languages," as Hebrew is significant to its pages, though it may not be, strictly speaking, featured. This was the winner of the 2022 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction.This is one of those books where both the title and the description of the book are not really telling you the truth about what the book is. Or at least, if you ask me, a book with the name The Netanyahus had really ought not have more than half of the book gone before anyone with this name appears on the page. They are important, in the sense that their eventual arrival does drive some of what passes for the action here, but this only goes so far. It's not about them! It's mostly about an elderly narrator looking back on a period of professional tumult in the middle of his career.When I was younger, I went to school with a lot of Jewish kids. On more than one occasion, one of the Jewish kids assumed I was also Jewish. A kid who was in band with me said my habit of picking up pennies if I saw them on the ground made me an honorary Jew. A friend made this proclamation after she witnessed me order a pastrami on rye. A third declared a demonstration of my morbid humor to be very Jewish. Adults would do this too. One time I went to get my hair cut like a week before Rosh Hashanah and the stylist wished me happy holidays. A friend's mother, whose house I had been going to for a couple of years at the point she said this, once wished me Happy Hanukkah in December. I absorbed their jokes about Jewish parents, about hypochondriac relatives, and all kinds of other things.None of which made me Jewish-adjacent enough to get just about any of the jokes in this book. Again, it bills itself as a comedy, except it's not! Unless it's funny to have the narrator getting a lecture from his perpetually disappointed mother-in-law while the text periodically inserts descriptions of the father-in-law in the bathroom unleashing a monster, toilet-clogging shit, which the FIL attempts to unclog with a plunger. Or funny for one set of your Jewish grandparents to hate the other because of grudges between cultures that dated back to the old world.Maybe I'm just neither Jewish nor literary enough to get it. In a post-text comment by the author, he describes having gotten to correspond with the literary critic, writer, and professor Harold Bloom towards the end of his life, during which correspondence Cohen eventually heard the anecdote that forms the back third or so of this book: Ben-Zion Netanyahu (father of Benjamin) showing up for an interview at Cornell with his entire family in tow unannounced, being absolutely rude to everyone, bombing the interview, bombing the guest lecture, bickering with his wife. The basic problem is this whole thing is not a book! It's a story to tell at a party - for Bloom himself perhaps when he was alive, or even just Cohen to swear that he heard it straight from Bloom's lips. The time a ten-year-old Benjamin Netanyahu was swept along with his idiot father, and the entire weird-ass family never once remarked on the fact that the seven-year-old kid showed up in diapers. If all you've got for symbolism is the sledgehammer of a family unexpectedly invading a house, being asked to take their shoes off, blowing into the house without doing it, then complaining the whole time after they comply with this modest request, well, you know.Cohen, through his narrator, the fictional (but not that fictional) Ruben Blum, lands some sick burns on the Netanyahu clan, about Ben-Zion's perpetual grievances about his own shortcomings, about the arrogance of the change of the family name from a banal reference to being from a mill town to "God's give," his unearned sense of entitlement, his apparently weird interpretation of the Spanish Inquisition that seemed to have no support in scholarship but lined up neatly with a Netanyahu-preferred way of viewing the state of Israel in its infancy in the 20th century. If this is the patriarch, could any son of his possibly have much good to offer in the world of geopolitics? The implied answer, of course, is no. And we know that Benjamin did not. Yet even if one is inclined as a matter of one's own politics to accept that every one of these burns is the truth, that does not make this any more of an interesting book to read. The few interesting bits, e.g. Blum's observation about "the church of the assumption," the contrast between the secular in-laws and the religious parents, petty departmental politics grudges, and so on, are scattered and don't come together into an interesting whole.This is one of those Pulitzer winners where I'm just floored by what merit they found in this. I will make the assumption, with a dose of cynicism, that a certain type of literary person who would be chosen to nominate/award Pulitzers was won over by the book-long reference to Bloom. I am not that type of person. I did not know Harold Bloom existed before reading the "Credits and Extra Credits" following the close of the novel. The process can award amazing books sometimes - last year's winner The Night Watchman was brilliant. The two recent wins for Colson Whitehead were great books. Even ones I was less overwhelmed by at least had something that felt interesting at the heart of them. So it's not like it's always bad. Or even often bad! But then sometimes there's... this.

At times immensely readable, at times a proper challenge - it can read more like an academic paper than a work of fiction - it‚Äôs difficult for me to form a coherent response to this book. I felt little emotional connection to it, and didn‚Äôt have much appetite for it, yet it certainly earned my regard and admiration. I read it with my Pulitzer Prize reading group, and probably wouldn‚Äôt have persisted with what felt like a task if that hadn‚Äôt been the case. It‚Äôs undeniably clever, but I constantly felt like I was missing the point or not quite in on the joke. Let me give you a bit of the flavour of the writing, and this is an excerpt that I did understand:
Just about a decade prior to the autumn I am recalling, the State of Israel was founded. In that minuscule country halfway across the globe, displaced and refugee Jews were busy reinventing themselves into a single people, united by the hatred and subjugations of contrary regimes, in a mass-process of solidarity aroused by gross antagonism. Simultaneously, a kindred mass-process was occurring here in America, where Jews were busy being deinvented, or uninvented, or assimilated, by democracy and market-forces, intermarriage and miscegenation. Regardless of where they were and the specific nature and direction of the proces, however, it remains an incontrovertible fact that nearly all of the world‚Äôs Jews were involved at midcentury in becoming something else; and that at this point of transformation, the old internal differences between them - of former citizenship and class, to say nothing of language and degree of religious observance - became for a brief moment more palpable than ever, giving one last death-rattle gasp.
The narrator of the story is Ruben Blum, the first Jewish professor on the faculty of Corbindale College - a ‚Äòsub-Ivy‚Äô college in New York state. A former Bronx Jew, of Russian/Ukranian immigrant parents, Blum‚Äôs speciality is the history of American economics. His family is rounded out by wife Edith and teenage daughter Judy. During the school year of 1959/60, Blum is just getting a firmer toehold into the community; if asked, he claims that he would say that domestic life is ‚Äòwonderful‚Äô, although he admits to himself (and confesses to the reader) that his wife is ‚Äòbored‚Äô and his daughter is ‚Äòangry‚Äô. If Blum and his family represent the mid-century Jewish American experience - a state of semi-assimilation - then the Netanyahu family represent something far more intractable. The first half of the book focuses on Ruben Blum, whilst the second half is given over to the visit of the Netanyahu family of the book‚Äôs title. (In the book‚Äôs Afterword - which Cohen titles ‚ÄòCredits & Extra Credit‚Äô - it‚Äôs revealed that the Netanyahu visit is actually based on a real visit to an American university, as recounted to the author by the famous academic Harold Bloom. ) I won‚Äôt entirely spoil the narrative surprise, but let‚Äôs just say that the visit is intense, comic, absurd and grotesque. It has been proposed that Corbindale might hire Dr Netanyahu - and presumably because of their shared Jewishness, Blum is given the responsibility of vetting Netanyahu‚Äôs references and hosting him during his visit. Unexpectedly, he brings the family - wife Tzila and their three sons - with him. I wasn‚Äôt sure, until the novel‚Äôs afterword, what was fact and was fiction. On reflection, it‚Äôs clear that the novel is attempting to elucidate how and why the United States became critical in the formation of the state of Israel. (At least that is one idea in the book, and there are plenty of others - most of them related to the Jewish experience, although Cohen is certainly very funny and knowledgeable about American academia.) The future Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu- the middle son of the Dr Netanyahu featured in this book - is characterised in this way by Cohen:
His reign, marked by the building of walls, the construction of settlements, and the normalisation of occupation and state violence against the Palestinians, represented the ultimate triumph of the formerly disgraced Revisionist vision promulgated by his father.
Reading this book was, in a way, a history lesson for me; but if anything, Cohen‚Äôs book is also (always?) a reminder that ‚Äòhistory‚Äô is just a construct shaped by the storyteller.

I wanted to like this book and enjoyed the first quarter or so, narrated by Ruben (Rube) Blum, where he relates the changes he has seen over a long career in academia, particularly the changes in students who have become intolerably sensitive and require coddling. But this is all just a slow build-up to the purpose of the story--taking a sledgehammer to the reputation of the real Netanyahu family. To achieve this, Blum recalls the train-wreck visit of Ben Zion Netanyahu, desperate to win a teaching position at Corbin College, where Blum, the only current Jewish faculty member, has been corralled into researching Netanyahu's academic background and chaperoning him through his visit. Blum resents this task, knowing he is only being asked because he is Jewish, as he and the visiting professor have nothing in common academically. Blum himself is totally apathetic Jewishly.In an end note, the author concedes that the book's premise was based on an anecdote told to him by the late Harold Bloom, about the historian Ben Zion Netanyahu, who indeed tried out for such a position at a college where Harold Bloom had taught, and apparently, it was a fiasco. This was thin gruel out of which to write a quasi-novel, based on real people and the memories of one now deceased witness. While Cohen can be very, very funny, when the point of a book is a mean-spirited attack on an entire family the humor begins to fail. In that same end note, Cohen also slams Bibi Netanyahu, the middle son of Ben Zion and former Israeli prime minister, even implicating him in the murder of Itzhak Rabin at that hands of extremist Yigal Amir. Cohen claims that Bibi didn't condemn extremists who attended his own political rallies with Rabin in effigy, insinuating that this may have led to Rabin's murder. I do not know whether this is true or not, but it is despicable for Cohen to identify Amir as "Orthodox" and driven by supposedly religious impulses without also noting that his evil act was condemed as evil such by Jews worldwide, including by the Orthodox community. He also slams many of Netanyahu's acts as PM that helped reduce the rate of terrorism in Israel, failing to note such terrorism even existed.And the novel itself is a failure on many levels. Themes that promise some exploration are dropped instantly. For example, the thoroughly secular Blum is drawn back into his painful memories of a religious upbringing by having to wade through Netanyahu's writings on the history of Jews in the Middle Ages. Will this lead to a new understanding of Blum's Jewish identity? No. It's a premise that is drop-shipped into the story but then is dropped, period. The Netanyahus themselves are so thoroughly obnoxious (Ben Zion, his wife, and their 3 sons) that any potential renewed interest Blum might have had in Jewish history or peoplehood would have been quashed.Additionally, Cohen inserts lengthy scenes, one with his parents (immigrant Jews who are not formally eduated) and one with his in-laws (secular, wealthy, and snobbish), seemingly to showcase various flavors of unappealing Jews. The parents are not part of the storyline on any ongoing basis. Blum's daughter, Judy, is a cynical high-school senior who is unhappy about her nose--another way in which Jewishness is negative in this story. But, so what? None of these characters or the scenes they are in add up to anything other than more evidence that so many manifestations of Jewishness, whether the smug, secular mother-in-law; the street savvy but crude father; the disaffected teenaged daughter, or the horrible Netanyahus themselves, are huge turn-offs.Cohen loves pretentious words, too, such as chthonic, verdigrised, coruscant, sudorous, sebacious, etc, but they do nothing to lift this disjointed story into something coherent. All it adds up to is an excuse for Cohen to exercise his anti-religious and anti-Israel bias. Talk about a turnoff.

I am absolutely in shock that this troubling book won a Pulitzer Prize. Maybe there are too many professors on the committee who were happy that this book, as well as Less, spoke to some of their personal teaching experiences. Perhaps they felt that honoring a Jewish author for writing a book that did not show one positive aspect of Jews, Judaism, Israel or the Netanyahus, was a socially acceptable way of criticizing Jews and Israel in general. No matter the reason, the result is deeply disturbing.Ruben Bloom, based on a real person, is the only Jewish professor at a college in upstate New York around 1960. His discussion about some of the issues created by that situation, were to me, the highlight of the book. Sadly, the highlights ended there.Ruben's character, as well as all of the characters, were pure stereotypes, seen often before. Ruben even describes himself with some of the same adjectives often used by Woody Allen, without Allen's clever humor. His daughter Judy, is another painful stereotype- a smart girl obsessed with getting her nose fixed. His in-laws are parodies. The only memorable family member is his father, who is given a good speech about the meaning of fairness in the world. Other than that, the parents are stereotypes as well.The most disturbing part of this book however, is its skewering of a real family. Cohen takes an anecdote about the Netanyahu family and uses it to thoroughly bash every aspect of every member of that family- even the youngest child. I have never seen anything like this deliberate hatchet job that Cohen has delivered in the guise of a novel. Many of the people that Cohen attacks are still alive, which makes it even more disturbing. In his afterward, Cohen confesses that the person Judy is based on asked to be made unrecognizable. He then has the nerve to skewer the real person, citing a letter that she wrote and making her seem deranged. He then attacks Benjamin Netanyahu's career and criticizes his political decisions. The Netanyahus isn't a novel. It is an attack piece. At some point, my main focus was on the viability of several libel suits.

Joshua Cohen has written a snarky and humorous book of speculative fiction about Benzion Netanyahu‚Äôs job interview at the fictional Corbin College in western New York during the winter of 1959-60. One of the buildings at the college is called Fredonia Hall. True there a town in New York called Fredonia, but I believe the real reference to Fredonia, the mythical country in the 1933 Marx Brothers movie ‚ÄúDuck Soup.‚Äù The book is patterned after his real-life visit to Cornell where he was hosted by Harold Bloom. Netanyahu brings his whole family with him including is wife and three kids, one of whom is his son Binyamin.Much of the book has to do with his host, economic historian Ruben Blum, his family, and his identity as the only Jewish faculty member. Because he is Jewish, he is chosen to host Netanyahu who is an expert on inquisition Spain, a subject Blum knows little. Blum comes from the family of an East European garment cutter, while his wife Edith comes from a German-Jewish family of a small factory owner. The conflicts are obvious and their teen aged daughter pines for a nose job. Here we have all kinds of identity issues rapped up into one family.The Netanyahus overwhelm the Blums wreaking havoc with their home and breaking their color TV, an anachronism here because in 1960 there were very few assistant professors who owned a color TV. Color television did not become a mass consumer product until 1964. In another anachronism he has Blum‚Äôs former employer CUNY, which was not formed until 1961. Further, Ruben condescends to call the Netanyahu family the ‚ÄúYahus.‚ÄùThe book is serious when it discusses Netanyahu‚Äôs thesis that antisemitism in inquisition Spain was racialized. It did not matter whether or not a Jew converted to Catholicism, it was their blood that kept them from being true Christians. Hitler would adopt a similar view 450 years later and to me that was reinforced when I visited an exhibition on converso Spain at the New Mexico Museum. Thus, if Judaism was racialized the only solution for Jews was to have a state of their own.I sense that Cohen really does not understand the Revisionist Zionist philosophy of Benzion Netanyahu. I did learn that Netanyahu was Jabotinsky‚Äôs, the founder of Revisionist Zionism, man in the United States until he died in 1940. Several years ago, I reviewed Hillel Halkin‚Äôs biography of Jabotinsky. There I learned that Jabotinsky and Netanyahu by implication understood that 1) there would be an inherent conflict between Jews and Arabs in Palestine, 2) Nazism was going to destroy European Jewry and 3) the Labor-Zionist socialist model was not going to work in Israel. Simply put Jabotinsky and Netanyahu were clear-eyed realists. I wish Cohen grasped that fact.Nevertheless, when you get beyond the issues I have raised, I believe the reader will learn much from the issues concerning the role of Jews in America, especially in a very non-Jewish community and will enjoy the comedic touches throughout the book.

I've never read anything quite like this before- a work of fiction that reads like creative non-fiction. The book somehow combines slapstick comedy, history, politics, academia, and religion to analyze the Jewish Question following the Holocaust and the establishment of the state of Israel. What is our place in the world following these major events? Is the future of Judaism assimilation as an American Jew living in a non-Jewish world? Or is the future Jewish nationalism that seeks to take control of our own history by any means necessary? This tension between American and Israeli Jews continues today- between Zionism and the diaspora. Between participating in the nationalist political project of Israel or forging along with creating our own Jewish identity elsewhere. The main character is Ruben Blum, a history professor at an Ithaca like college town in random upstate New York. The history department is interviewing Ben Zion Netanyahu, father of Bibi, for a position at the college, and thru a seemingly meaningless encounter between Blum's Jewish American family and Netanyahu's Israeli family, we are given something of an allegory for the tension that exists between the Israeli and American Jewish communities: who were we in the past and who are we going to be in the future?For such intense subject matter, the book reads extremely light and humorous. Sprinkled throughout the slapstick is an extremely nuanced look at historiography and the role of history shaping Jewish identity. Netanyahu is a revisionist historian who offers an alternate interpretation of the Spanish Inquisition, in that it was the first time Jews were perceived as a race and set in motion the violent European anti-Semitism that followed in the later centuries. This idea of historical revisionism is a major theme of the book- how your interpretation of history shapes your identity. How revising and changing history shapes your identity.Blum, a historian of American history, and Netanyahu, a historian of Jewish history, have had their identities shaped by history they study. Blum is very happy with his upstate New York living, even when his parents and parents in law believe that he is not engaging in Judaism enough. Blum is an assimilated American who mostly participates in Judaism just socially, not religiously. Netanyahu is a nationalist Israeli who doesn't think too favorably of Blum's assimilation and isolation upstate. Netanyahu's criticism of American Jewry are from his Zionist beliefs that are shaped by the Jewish history he studies. The identities of these two men create a fascinating tension that is explored throughout the book.Check out this book if you are interested in history and history's relationship to political identity.Some moments you'll find yourself laughing, other moments pondering your existence. It's all great fun.

What a fascinating, through-provoking, enjoyable and funny book this is. While at some sections a linguistic challenge, it is nevertheless a gripping, really genre-bending story that puts together a funny campus novel with a discourse on the nature and history of Jewishness, Judaism, Zionism and American-Jewish experience (and their various stereotypes and tropes), as well as the history of the Spanish Inquisition.The story is a fictionalised narrative of a job interview and a visiting lecture by Bibi Netanyahu's father, Benzion (or rather Ben-Zion), taking place in a small college in northwestern (not Upstate) New York State - something between Cornell (where Benzion actually taught) and to a very limited degree Yale (where Harold Bloom, whose actual memory the story was spun off, taught for ages). Narrated through the eyes of a taxation studies historian, professor Ruben Blum ("a Jewish historian - but not a historian of the Jews") tasked with chaperoning the Netanyahus during their visit due to the fact that he was the first (ever) Jew at the school, whose family exhibits the conflicts and aspirations of the 1950s America, it is also somewhat a story of the crises of identity or identities, and the conflicts between religion and secularism.Some parts would be probably funnier or would bring greater insights had I been a part of any of the groups directly sharing the experiences presented in the narrative, I nevertheless found it amusing and the book's arguments about Benzion Netanyahu's scholarship and theses intriguing. Cohen's pure mastery is in creating a semi-fictional story taking place in 1960, with discussions of the history of Revisionist Zionism and Inquisition, that feels strikingly relevant and thought-provoking in today's (and 2021s) environment and situation, when one of the characters of the book has once again become the Prime Minister of Israel, this time relying on even more divisive platform and allies. And it makes it even better that Cohen deals with this real-life continuation of the characters and theses of the book in the appendix.An absolute joy to read, even better as the Fitzcarraldo Edition of the book feels like a piece of art.

I don't know. I wanted to like it. The book is based on an anecdote told by Mr. Cohen's friend and admirer, the great Harold Bloom, who listed Mr. Cohen's "Book of Numbers" as the lone contemporary choice among books that we all must read. I slogged through "Book of Numbers" and found things to admire in it, but did not share Mr. Bloom's enthusiasm. I liked this one a bit better than "Book of Numbers" but overall had much the same reaction. The shifting narrative voice is good. It's clear that we can't completely trust the principal narrator, Ruben Blum, though he sees the world more clearly than most of the people around him. So we are given different perspectives on Netanyahu to fill out the portrait through two chapters comprised of recommendation letters from other scholars, and then Netanyahu is given the chance to damn himself with his own words in his job interview and his guest lecture to the academic community. I liked the the portrayal of the senior Netanyahu as a man who is personally repellant, difficult, thin skinned, overly academic, philosophically dangerous and having a family from hell, but still undeniably brilliant. As the anti-recommendation letter from Israel says about him, he is the kind of scholar who should be sent to a corner of the library to study and not allowed to teach or probably even to publish. As he expounds his theories, my reaction, which I think Mr. Cohen intended, was "Bullshit, bullshit, bullshit, but wait a minute, maybe not completely bullshit." That's a common theme with the theories a lot of dangerous demagogues.Though the book is billed as a tribute to Harold Bloom, it is in some ways more a tribute to Philip Roth, with its prose style, its small town college setting and its obsessive Jewishness. It was only missing the sex, but that also makes a brief appearance at the end.Still in the end the book just didn't do it for me. I'm not entirely sure why. I think that it may be because it feels to me like Mr. Cohen is trying too hard. I feel the same way about Michael Chabon though Mr. Chabon's version of trying too hard expresses itself in different ways.

Eventually, the protagonist professor is called upon to host a visiting Jewish professor from Israel who has applied for a job. My page was‚Ä¶too blank, team. Too blank. Hilarious. I missed the e n t i r e point of this novel-that‚Äôs-really-a-thinly-veiled-historical-account. "My name is Ruben Blum and I'm an, yes an, historian."That's the first line, and I already regretted getting this book from the library instead of purchasing my own copy. By the end of the first paragraph, I knew I would need my own copy sooner rather than later, just to write in and underline. As it was, I made everyone in the house read the first paragraph.The more I think about it, the more I think this first line has everything to do with the themes of the book. Who knows if that's what the author intended. I learned the proper indefinite pronoun to precede historian is "an." I don't remember which teacher it was (I've been lucky to have some great ones), but I know in my heart's heart that it's correct, and everyone else is wrong--like my daughter.So here I am, absolutely convinced of the correctness of my belief and tradition, and a young upstart challenges me on it. Is it for political reasons? Religious reasons? Historical reasons? All of these? Doesn't matter. The differences between us have been exposed.And that's what this book is about. Joshua Cohen nails the ending. The whole thing is so great, on so many levels. It's funny, a little heartbreaking, thought-provoking, and has just the right amount of pathos. I'm still right about an historian.

I enjoyed the book on many levels. First, it resonated with me culturally. While I didn't experience the degree of cultural stereotypical behavior satirized in the book, I definitely have experienced some, so it was amusing to see it so prominently displayed. Second, I found the portrait of life at a small, middle-tier, liberal arts college interesting and amusing. The entire description rang true for me. Middling, self-important intellectuals weaponizing their "power" wherever possible. I'm glad I didn't go into academics. I was particularly galled by the theology professor accusing Blum of theft of this pen and then calling him an empty suit (this of the same Blum who relieved him of embarrassment for not knowing any Hebrew). Third, I enjoyed the erudition of Cohen on the different types of Zionism as well as Netanyahu's (mis)interpretation of the Inquisition (including the non-recommendation letter from a colleague at Hebrew University). Fourth, I like Cohen's writing. He's excellent. Finally, like many, I found the portion on the Netanyahus to be my least favorite. There were a lot of cringeworthy moments (a la Michael Scott from The Office) that were funny at times, but it was too over the top for me. It needn't have been so unrealistic, down to the absurd ending, to have entertained. In fact, I think the reality of the Netanyahus' actual behavior would have improved the book. But I am gilding the lily here. This was an excellent, thought-provoking, well-written novel. Two post-scripts. I read an account by the author of one of his conversations with Professor Bloom. To say that the conversation ascended the lofty heights of literary scholarship above the head of this reader is a major understatement. The author definitely has real scholarly chops.And the book does explain, in part, Benjamin Netanyahu, who did more to set back the peace process in Israel with his policies than anyone else in Israeli history. After all, he was forged in the fires of his father's zealotry. He, of course, rather ironically, treated Palestinian Arabs with the same sort of treatment as the Middle-Age Spaniards treated Iberian Jews, albeit with less extermination, that his father spent 80 years decrying.

Although the parents of the narrator and his in-laws present ample comedic material in a farce about assimilated Jews living in an ‚Äúupstate‚Äù New York college town where the narrator works for a mediocre, anodyne college in somewhat of a sinecure, Joshua Cohen‚Äôs The Netanyahus reserves its most biting distain for bratty children since. . .well. . .Jane Austen. And while the children steal the show whenever they appear, the crux of the novel involves the easy-to-dislike patriarch of the Netanyahu clan‚Äîand the father of the former Prime Minister of Israel, the omnipotent right-wing politician, Benjamin Natanyahu. The elder Netanyahu, a controversial scholar on the Spanish Inquisition, breezes into town like a bull in a China shop and presents himself at various committees and college social functions where he is being considered for a tenure track position. The result of a radicalized Jew in Goyland is the premise for this much-touted farce and slapstick of academic life interrupted by the arrival of an idiot savant and his uncouth family. An entertaining college farce, not nearly as tragic and timeless as John Williams‚Äôs Stoner, but ultimately more gratifying than anything by Kingsley Amis.

In this blend of fiction and nonfiction, the winner of the Pulitzer Prize in fiction, Cohen wrote a literary story of a bleak figure of Benzion Netanyahu in a comical way. 4.5 stars. I had to sit with this for a few days to try to get a handle on how I felt about the book. Let me start by saying I liked it. There's no question about that. Especially as the book began, and as I got to know Professor Blum and his family. I found him an empathetic protagonist. The book was so amusing, and I was thinking all sorts of nice thoughts about what a funny people we Jews are. But then the parents and in-laws show up, and they're... extra. After that, the eponymous Netanyahus enter the novel and they're... awful. I mean, they are over-the-top, hard to believe awful! And this depiction made me feel more than a little uncomfortable. In a world so full of anti-Semitism, do we really need to fuel the fire? (To be emphatically clear, I do not believe Joshua Cohen to have an anti-Semitic bone in his body, to have done anything inappropriate in the writing of this novel, or to have had any bad intent.) It's actually unusual for me to feel uncomfortable when reading a book, and generally upon reflection, I find myself impressed by any author who can inspire that intense a reaction. I'm not sure if that was the author's intent, or if anyone else had a similar reaction. (Isn't it awesome that we all experience books our own way!) What IS obvious is that he was mining history for humor. But as with the best comic novels, there's a lot more going on under the surface, with all sorts of social commentary going on, with a soupcon of academic satire, and yes, well-depicted historical fiction.The author's note at the end, sharing historical notes and the story behind the story was tremendously interesting and enjoyable, and should not be missed.Other readers, what was your reaction to the book? Please share!

The title of ‚ÄúThe Netanyahus‚Äù is click-bait: it lures you into buying a book which is irrelevant if you are interested in political satire about the famous (or infamous) Israeli political dynasty. The Netanyahu family appears in less(!) than half of the book, and when it does, it is only to wallow in stereotypes about boorish Israelis in a poor attempt at slap-stick comedy. This book is the epitome of literary laziness: instead of writing a biting satire about a controversial political dynasty, the book uses cheap toilet-humor, vulgarity, impoliteness, and stereotypes about different Jewish groups (Israeli, German, Eastern European) to try to sell this dreck as humorous literature. (Dreck is Yiddish for rubbish or excrement, by the way).When I started reading the book, I was shocked this won a literary prize. When I continued my perusal, I was stunned that this got published. It has many anachronisms (places things that don‚Äôt belong in an era into that era), its rendering of historical views on Spanish Jewry are puerile, and most of all ‚Äì it is utterly irrelevant. Who cares about a fake version of Harold Bloom (called Ruben Blum in the book) and a non-sensical account of an allegedly disastrous campus visit by a scholar called Ben-Zion Netanyahu, whom we know - although not from the book - that he did get hired in the end? After painfully treading through the book, I arrived at the author‚Äôs afterword in which he reveals the important historical role of the Netanyahus, which most of us know already. He would not have had to remind us of this, had he written a fine political satire in which this significance would have made itself known. What a waste of time and money! If you are looking for good satire, look elsewhere.

Ruben Blum, a specialist in taxation history, is a Jewish professor at the fictional Corbin University. Despite his own ambivalence towards his Jewish American identity, he is asked to join a hiring committee considering employing Benzion Netanyahu, a [very real] professor who is a fervent Zionist first and historian of the Iberian Inquisition second. The novel culminates with the Blums hosting not just Netanyahu and his wife, but rather the whole family.I‚Äôm not sure why this book worked as well as it did for me, but, man, did it work. It is a fascinating meditation on Jewish American identity, especially in light of the still relatively new state of Israel. The story itself is a highly fictionalized account of an interaction that Harold Bloom had with Netanyahu. As a side note, Cohen states in the afterword that his characterization of the Netanyahus was meant to be realistic, even though the Blum family doesn‚Äôt have quite as clear of a historical counterpart.I found Blum to be a thoughtful narrator. Cohen weaves in modern issues, but is able to transcend the specifics and circle in on larger questions of identity that stand in every generation. That‚Äôs not to say that this isn‚Äôt still a deeply Jewish book - it is. However, the specificity grounds the narrative. Even though this is a cultural conversation where I have almost no skin in the game, it still felt like a vital conversation.I found Netanyahu‚Äôs character particularly well-realized. He is combative, but not mean. Just by reading about this one incident, I could see why he produced such extreme reactions from colleagues. He is a zealot, through and through. His scholarship has a divine prerogative backing it. Blum, as mild mannered as he is, didn‚Äôt stand a chance.Also, this book is legitimately funny. While it has a wry sense of humor through much of the book, once the Netanyahu‚Äôs arrive, it‚Äôs no holds barred. The kids, in particular, are hilarious in the same way It‚Äôs Always Sunny in Philadelphia is hilarious - you want to hate them. I don‚Äôt know how historically accurate these characterizations are, but imagining the current prime minister of Israel as an unruly delinquent made me laugh.

After the first dozen pages or so I thought this was five stars material. Funny and wise observations (e.g. on wokeness) and preparing the setting. We have a Jewish historian, Ruben Blum (based somehow on Harold Bloom), at a some small New York university. Unlike the current trend in nonfiction to oversell a work in the subtitle, The Netanyahus ‚Äî which is fiction ‚Äî is transparently accurate with "An Account of a Minor and Ultimately Even Negligible Episode in the History of a Very Famous Family." I would argue the publisher could have safely and honestly upgraded to "Astonishing Account" or "Hilarious Account."The Netanyahus opens a little slow, introducing "an historian" named Ruben Blum but picks up speed as it fills out some family history and gets him situated at a small liberal arts college in New York State in about 1960. The "negligible episode" of the subtitle doesn't begin until the second half of this relatively short book. Once the Netanyahus arrive ‚Äî yes, Bibi himself as a child, plus his two brothers and their parents ‚Äî the book takes off, and I couldn't put it down. It starts funny, moves to crazy, and ends with jaw-dropping. And here's where I'm not sure if this fictionalized account is ‚Äî to borrow from the TV meme ‚Äî "ripped from the headlines," "based on real events," "inspired by real events," or more like "a satirical and fantastical account of what could have happened." The "Credits & Extra Credits" afterword implies the book hews closer to the truth than you would think possible.For me, this was a surprise Pulitzer Prize fiction winner in 2022 ‚Äîit hadn't been on my radar ‚Äî so a hearty thanks to the Pulitzer committee!

This audiobook was quite well done, with sound effects (doorbells, phones, music, etc)--I think audiobooks have as much potential to be true audio experiences as old radio shows. Very few even try, but this one certainly does--though some of the musical interludes were way too long (the chapter breaks, maybe?).I am always ready to admit my frustration with books that are "based on history" ie, present real people in real-ish situations and write around it. I hate this, especially when featuring living people or their immediate descendants. It is fake history, there are no standards, and often presents a negative image (which may or may not be accurate--but there are no sources!!). So, much of this story annoyed me. BUT--the sections that can truly be considered a "campus novel" were hilarious. The politics of departments, the infighting in class schedules and the ownership of subjects were absolutely hilarious. I truly laughed, especially in the section where Blum explains that though his history department has a reputation as being progressive ahead of its time in that it focused less on Europe, it wasn't because of any anti-colonial belief. It was because the chair. wants to be the only Europeanist in the department. Europe was his, and he would not hire anyone who might compete with him. This is so hilariously believable AND it is also hilariously believable that that would get twisted into the department being ahead of its time (when really it was the opposite--old WASP can;t tolerate any "competition").So--this evened out for me. Good audio production, hilarious and infuriating sections.

I'm not sure why this novel, based on a real-life event, took me such a long time to get through, but it did. When I was reading it, I was totally engaged but I had to keep reminding myself of that when I picked it up again. In any case, it's a wild ride that works on many levels. Set in 1960, on the campus of a would-be Ivy League college, the place of American assimilation, it is comedic and dramatic, polemic, and provides an alternate history of Jewish migration and assimilation, and a new view on the Spanish Inquisition, and highlights the tensions within the Jewish identity. Though the parents of Professor of History Ruben Blum are still religious Jews, he has left the Bronx and his upbringing behind, settled for the last couple of years with his wife and daughter in this small upstate New York town. The Blums are assimilated, even as he is the only Jewish professor at the college. Then he is tasked with shepherding and opining on whether the college should hire Ben-Zion Netanyahu - in real life, the father of Bibi Netanyahu, the long-lasting Israeli Prime Minister only recently ousted. The "Yahus" as the Blums end up calling them, descend on their home, in a snowstorm, creating chaos, and it is up to Ruben to make sure Ben-Zion gets to his committee meeting, his lecture, and so forth.

I went into this without expecting much--can't even remember why I decided to put the book on my TBR--but was pleasantly surprised at how much I liked it.The hilarious story of a visit by Benzion Netanyahu and his family to a small college in semi-rural New York looks at Jewish-American identity in the post-World War 2 years. The writing is wonderful, even if at times the story didn't completely hold together, and the ending struck me as somewhat unbelievable (I hope the ending is fiction!). The Netanyahu's scholarship is presented as being somewhat controversial, and indeed there is still controversy around his conclusions. Nevertheless, I think Cohen has a little bit of sympathy for Benzion, even if he is presented as being overbearing and comical at times. Cohen obviously has no sympathy with Benzion's wife and three children. Joshua Cohen takes issue with Zionism for an oft-ignored reason in our climate of progressive anti-Zionism: the ideology's insistence on the erasure of Jewish life in the Diaspora. At a moment in which some of the world‚Äôs most staunch Zionists live in the Diaspora--especially the U.S.--Cohen reminds us, by brilliant way of Bibi Netanyahu's father Ben-Zion, that Zionism is explicitly founded on a disgust for Diaspora Jewry. (Which helps to explain, perhaps, why America‚Äôs most fervent Zionists are not Jews but right-wing Christian nationalists).But, at its core, The Netanyahus is a family drama and a comedy of manners. Cohen's ability to balance both the intellectual and emotional aspects of its narrative makes the Netanyahus one of the best books I've read on Israel, American-Jewish identity, and postwar America in general.
